summary: This Associated Press article from March 5, 2020, reports that the Justice Department has opened a criminal investigation into potential misconduct by guards and the flow of contraband at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York, where Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide in August 2019. The investigation was triggered by information that a gun may have been smuggled into the facility, leading to a lockdown that has restricted inmate access to lawyers and delayed legal proceedings.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York City
keyFacts: The Justice Department opened a criminal investigation into potential misconduct by guards and contraband flow at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York, where Jeffrey Epstein died.
The investigation was triggered by information that a gun may have been smuggled into the MCC, leading to a lockdown that restricted inmates to their cells and denied them access to lawyers.
During the lockdown, contraband including cellphones was found, but no gun was located.
David Patton, head of Federal Defenders of New York, stated the lockdown violated inmates' constitutional rights and caused delays in sentencings and hearings.
The two correctional officers assigned to watch Epstein's unit when he died were alleged to have been sleeping and shopping online, and later forged records.
